revision.text:
{{BLP refimprove|date=November 2010}}
'''Richard David McCormick''' (July 4, 1940- ) is an [[Americans|American]] business executive.
==Biography== McCormick served as CEO of US West from 1990 to 1998.<ref name="wells1">[https://www.wellsfargo.com/about/corporate/boardofdirectors/mccormick Richard D. McCormick, director since 1983], Wells Fargo website, Retrieved November 15, 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051119170959/https://www.wellsfargo.com/about/corporate/boardofdirectors/mccormick |date=November 19, 2005 }}</ref> He was also a director of [[Wells Fargo & Company]] (1983-2010) and an honorary chairman of the [[International Chamber of Commerce]] (ICC).
McCormick was born in [[Fort Dodge, Iowa]], the son of Elmo Eugene McCormick and Virgilla (Lawler) McCormick. He received his BS degree in electrical engineering from [[Iowa State University]] in 1961. During his time as an undergraduate he was a member of the [[Phi Gamma Delta]] Fraternity. Post graduation he went to work for [[AT&T]] as an engineer in [[Kansas City, Missouri]].<ref name="chairin92"/>
On June 29, 1963, he married Mary Patricia Smola, and had four children.<ref name="chairin92"/>
He moved to [[Northwestern Bell]] in 1969, rising to the presidency of the [[Omaha]]-based company in 1982. A year after the divestiture of the [[Bell System]], he went to [[Denver]] in 1985 as executive vice president of [[US West]], Inc., the new regional Bell operating company.<ref name="chairin92"/> McCormick was elected president and chief operating officer in 1986, chief executive officer in 1990, and chairman in 1992 (replacing Jack A. MacAllister in both instances).<ref name="chairin92">Bryant, Adam. (4 April 1992) [https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10614F63D5E0C778CDDAD0894DA494D81 President of U S West to Become Chairman], ''[[The New York Times]]'', Retrieved November 15, 2010</ref>
In 1995 McCormick was named chairman of the [[United States Council for International Business]], the US affiliate of the International Chamber of Commerce. He stepped down as chairman and was named vice chairman in February 2001. Elected chairman of the International Chamber of Commerce in 2001, he retired in 2003 and was given the emeritus title of honorary chairman.<ref>[http://www.uscib.org/index.asp?documentID=1816 Richard D. McCormick bio], USCIB webpage, n.d. Retrieved December 15, 2011.</ref>
Having been elected a director of [[Norwest Bank]] in 1983, upon the merger with [[Wells Fargo & Company]] in 1998 he became a director of Wells Fargo. McCormick retired as CEO of US West in 1998 and as chairman of the board of directors in 1999. Solomon J. Trujillo replaced him as chairman.<ref name="newchair">(12 May 1999) [https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00E11F9395B0C718DDDAC0894D1494D81 U S West Elects New Chairman], ''[[The New York Times]]'', Retrieved November 15, 2010</ref> In January, 1999 McCormick was appointed vice president of [[International Chamber of Commerce|International Chamber of Commerce (ICC)]] and in January, 2001 he became the president of the body.<ref name=prn8jan>{{cite news|title=Former US WEST CEO Elected VP of International Chamber of Commerce; will Become President in 2 Years|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Former+U+S+WEST+CEO+Elected+VP+of+International+Chamber+of+Commerce%3b...-a053536924|accessdate= March 25, 2013|newspaper=PR Newswire|date=January 8, 1999|location=Geneva}}</ref>
In the past McCormick served on the boards of [[Nortel Networks Corporation]], [[United Technologies Corporation]], [[Health Trio]], [[UAL Corporation]], [[Wells Fargo & Company]], and [[Unocal]], and as a trustee for the Denver Art Museum.
Active in Republican politics, he has been a member of [[George W. Bush]] for President, Bush-Cheney '04, [[John McCain]] 2008, and the Freedom and Free Enterprise Political Action Committee.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox president| name=Rómulo Betancourt | image= RB 1975.jpg | order= 47th & 54th [[President of Venezuela]] | term_start=19 October 1945 | term_end=17 February 1948 | predecessor=[[Isaías Medina Angarita]] | successor=[[Rómulo Gallegos]] | term_start2=February 13, 1959 | term_end2=March 13, 1964 | predecessor2=[[Edgar Sanabria]] | successor2=[[Raúl Leoni]] | office3=Senator for life | term_start3=1964 | term_end3=1981 | birth_name=Rómulo Ernesto Betancourt Bello | birth_date={{birth date|df=yes|1908|2|22}} | birth_place=[[Guatire]], [[Miranda (state)|Miranda state]], [[Venezuela]] | death_date={{death date and age|df=yes|1981|9|28|1908|2|22}} | death_place= [[New York City]], [[United States]] | party=[[Acción Democrática]] | signature=Firma betancourt.png | spouse=Carmen Valverde (Div.) (d.1977)
Renée Hartmann Viso (1920-1991)| |}} '''Rómulo Ernesto Betancourt Bello''' (22 February 1908 – 28 September 1981; {{IPA-es|ˈromulo betaŋˈkuɾ}}), known as "The Father of Venezuelan Democracy", was the 47th and 54th [[President of Venezuela]], serving from 1945 to 1948 and again from 1959 to 1964, as well as leader of [[Acción Democrática]], [[Venezuela]]'s dominant political party in the 20th century. Betancourt, one of Venezuela's most important political figures, led a tumultuous and highly controversial career in Latin American politics. Periods of exile brought Betancourt in contact with various Latin American countries as well as the [[United States]], securing his legacy as one of the most prominent international leaders to emerge from 20th-century Latin America. Scholars credit Betancourt as the [[Founding Father]] of modern democratic Venezuela. ==Early years== [[File:Rómulo Betancourt during his infancy.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Rómulo Betancourt during his childhood]] [[File:Betancourt, 1936.jpg|thumb|150px|Betancourt in 1936]] Rómulo Betancourt was born in [[Guatire]], a town near [[Caracas]]. His parents were Luis Betancourt Bello (from [[Canary Islands|Canary origins]]) and Virginia Bello Milano. He attended a private school in Guatire, followed by high school at the ''Liceo Caracas'' in Caracas. He studied law at the [[Central University of Venezuela]].Fundación para la Cultura Urbana. 2009. Rómulo Betancourt: crónica visual. page 16. Cronología RB. As a young man he was expelled from Venezuela for radical agitation and moved to Costa Rica where he founded, and led, a number of radical and [[Communist]] student groups.Nathaniel Weyl. 1960. Red Star Over Cuba. page 3. OOC:60-53203. In the early 1930s, while in [[Costa Rica]], he became at the young age of 22, the one of the main militants of that country's [[Communist Party]].Nathaniel Weyl. 1960. Red Star Over Cuba. pages 3-5. OOC:60-53203.Robert Jackson Alexander Romulo Betancourt and the Transformation of Venezuela, Transaction Books, New Brunswick and London 1982 p.74 In 1937, after resigning from the Communist Party and returning to Venezuela, he founded the Partido Democrático Nacional, which became an official political party in 1941 as [[Acción Democrática]] (AD). Colombian leader [[Jorge Eliécer Gaitán]] claimed Betancourt had "offered him arms and money to launch a revolution in Colombia" which was part of Betancourt's alleged plan to build a solid phalanx of left-wing regimes in the Caribbean.Nathaniel Weyl. 1960. Red Star Over Cuba. page 4-5. OOC:60-53203. It was alleged by Azula Barrera and Colombian President [[Mariano Ospina Pérez]] that Betancourt had supported the armed rising at the 1948 Inter-American Conference ([[Bogotazo]]) that left more than a thousand people dead, among these the political assassination of [[Jorge Eliécer Gaitán]].Nathaniel Weyl. 1960. Red Star Over Cuba. page 25, 30-31. OOC:60-53203. This started a new volatile political period in neighboring Colombia some claim continues to this day with [[FARC]]. ==First term as president== {{Main article|El Trienio Adeco}} [[File:JRG, 1945.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Members of the Revolutionary Government Junta, from left to right: Mario Ricardo Vargas, [[Raúl Leoni]], Valmore Rodríguez, Rómulo Betancourt, [[Carlos Delgado Chalbaud]], Edmundo Fernández and Gonzalo Barrios. Miraflores Palace, 1945]] [[File:RB, votando en los comicios del 27 de octubre de 1946.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Rómulo Betancourt voting at the [[Venezuelan Constituent Assembly election, 1946]]]] Betancourt became president in 1945 by means of a military coup d'état and, during his time in office, completed an impressive agenda. His accomplishments included the declaration of universal [[suffrage]], the institution of social reforms, and securing half of the profits generated by foreign oil companies for Venezuela. His government worked closely with the [[International Refugee Organization]] to aid European refugees and displaced persons who could not or would not return home after World War II; his government assumed responsibility for the legal protection and resettlement of tens of thousands of refugees inside Venezuela. The refugee initiative was the subject of great controversies within his government with the winning side led by Betancourt's secretary of Agriculture, [[Eduardo Mendoza Goiticoa|Eduardo Mendoza]]. ===Reform of the oil industry=== In 1941, before AD's entry into policymaking, Venezuela received 85,279,158 [[Venezuelan bolívar|bolívars]] from oil taxes, out of a total oil value of 691,093,935 bolivars. Before Betancourt's changes in the taxing system, the state of Venezuela was making only a fraction of what foreign oil companies were making in profit. President Betancourt had overthrown the [[Isaías Medina Angarita]] government which enacted a law to tax oil companies up to 60%, and reserved for the government the right to raise more taxes as needed. Betancourt changed the law to "Fifty Fifty." One of Betancourt's original objectives was the [[nationalization]] of the country's oil industry. Mexico had nationalized its oil industry in 1938, and because its economy was more [[Diversification (finance)|diversified]] than Venezuela's, there was little to no backlash. Though oil nationalization became one of AD's main objectives, Venezuela's economy was not stable enough to handle potential boycotts by foreign oil companies and would have left nation fiscally vulnerable. Rationalizing the complications of nationalization at the time, Betancourt's government raised taxes on oil production instead accomplishing the same goal: Venezuela's oil riches to benefit Venezuelans. In the late 1940s Venezuela was producing close to {{convert|500000000|oilbbl}} annually and as production climbed, the tax followed. Venezuela was the Allies' top oil supplier during the wars occurring in the European continent. Betancourt identified this potential to play an important historical role, using the knowledge to his nation's advantage transforming Venezuela into a global player. Germany then lacked reliable access to oil limiting troop movements. Some historians identify this vulnerability a deciding factor in Hitler's defeat. Venezuelan oil played a key role. According to Betancourt, a spike in taxes was just as effective as nationalizing the oil industry, "Tax income was increased from then to such a degree that nationalization was unnecessary to obtain maximum economic benefits for the people of the country". Oil companies were forced to cede to the demands of labor unions and no longer entitled to make larger profits than the Venezuelan government. As a result, Betancourt's government generally had full support of the labor unions as the administration openly encouraged workers to organize. In 1946, 500 labor unions were created. Another notable achievement of Betancourt's first administration include the termination of the [[Concession (contract)|concession]] policy, the initial development of [[Oil refinery|refineries]] within Venezuela, and tremendous improvement in worker conditions and pay. [[Juan Pablo Pérez Alfonso]] served as Minister of Development in Betancourt's first term. === Government Junta cabinet (1945–1948) === {{Col-begin}} {{Col-1-of-2}} {| cellpadding="1" cellspacing="4" style="margin:1px; border:1px solid Black; float:left" |- !bgcolor="#dcdcdc" colspan=3|MinistriesRómulo Betancourt Foundation (2006). "Political Anthology of Rómulo Betancourt, Fourth Volume 1945–1948." |- |align="left"|'''OFFICE'''||align="left"|'''NAME'''||align="left"|'''TERM''' |- !bgcolor="black" colspan=3| |- |align="left"|[[President of Venezuela|President]]||align="left"|'''Rómulo Betancourt'''||align="left"|1945–1948 |- |align="left"|Home Affairs||align="left"|'''Valmore Rodríguez'''||align="left"|1945–1946 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Mario Ricardo Vargas'''||align="left"|1946–1948 |- !bgcolor="black" colspan=3| |- |align="left"|Outer Relations||align="left"|'''Carlos Morales'''||align="left"|1945–1947 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''[[Gonzalo Barrios (politician)|Gonzalo Barrios]]'''||align="left"|1947–1948 |- |align="left"|Finance||align="left"|'''Carlos D'Ascoli'''||align="left"|1945–1947 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Manuel Pérez Guerrero'''||align="left"|1947–1948 |- |align="left"|Defense||align="left"|'''[[Carlos Delgado Chalbaud]]'''||align="left"|1945–1948 |- |align="left"|Development||align="left"|'''[[Juan Pablo Pérez Alfonso]]'''||align="left"|1945–1948 |- |align="left"|Public Works||align="left"|'''Luis Lander'''||align="left"|1945–1946 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Eduardo Mier y Terán'''||align="left"|1946–1947 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Edgar Pardo Stolk'''||align="left"|1947–1948 |- |align="left"|Education||align="left"|'''Humberto García Arocha'''||align="left"|1945–1946 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Antonio Anzola Carrillo'''||align="left"|1946–1947 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''[[Luis Beltrán Prieto Figueroa]]'''||align="left"|1947–1948 |- |align="left"|Labor||align="left"|'''[[Raúl Leoni]]'''||align="left"|1945–1948 |- |align="left"|Communications||align="left"|'''Mario Ricardo Vargas'''||align="left"|1945–1946 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Valmore Rodríguez'''||align="left"|1946–1947 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Antonio Martín Araujo'''||align="left"|1947–1948 |- |align="left"|Agriculture||align="left"|'''[[Eduardo Mendoza Goiticoa]]'''||align="left"|1945–1947 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Ricardo Montilla'''||align="left"|1947–1948 |- |align="left"|Health and Social Assistance||align="left"|'''Edmundo Fernández'''||align="left"|1945–1948 |- |align="left"|Secretary of the Junta||align="left"|'''Luis Beltrán Prieto Figueroa'''||align="left"|1945–1947 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''José Giacoppini Zárraga'''||align="left"|1947–1948 |- |} {{Clear}} {{Col-2-of-2}} {{Col-end}} ==Third exile== [[File:RB during his exile in Havana, 1949.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Rómulo Betancourt during his exile in Havana, Cuba, 1949]] On 27 November 1948, [[Carlos Delgado Chalbaud]], [[Marcos Pérez Jiménez]] and Luis Felipe Llovera Páez launched the [[1948 Venezuelan coup d'état]] and overthrew the elected president [[Rómulo Gallegos]], and Betancourt went into exile in New York City. In exile he planned a political return sustained on democratic principles and open elections legitimizing his national leadership role. His forward vision and strategy was successful and Betancourt was elected president by his own people upon returning to Venezuela. He had been determined to expose to the world the political problems and dictatorships that plagued the country through most of its modern history – a risky proposition. "Betancourt's third, and longest, period of exile was a time of enormous frustration. In the prime of his life --for roughly the decade of his forties-- he was forced into relative inactivity and obscurity. He traveled extensively, living in Cuba, Costa Rica, and Puerto Rico, and remained a leader of an opposition-in-exile to the Perez Jimenez dictatorship. And of course wrote 'Venezuela: Oil and Politics'. A beach home outside of San Juan (Puerto Rico) provided a quiet refuge for this work," wrote Franklin Tugwell in his Introduction to the 1978 English publication of Betancourt's book. "The preparation of this book has been as hectic as the life of the author. I wrote it first between the years 1937–39 while I was underground hiding from the police. It could not be published then because no Venezuelan publisher would dare risk printing a book written by one who was in such compromising position. The only typewritten copy was among my personal papers and it disappeared with them when a military patrol plundered the house I was living in when the constitutional government was overthrown on 24 November 1948. Thus most of the material from the first draft was lost. "I believe that 'the dead command,' although not in the sense that reactionaries have traditionally given the phrase. When they die they give the command for an ideal of human excellence, obliging those who survive to finish their work," wrote Romulo Betancourt in the Prologue to the first edition of "Venezuela: Oil and Politics". The book published in Mexico City by Editorial Fondo de Cultura Economica in 1956 was prohibited from circulating in Venezuela. Effectively censored; yet Betancourt persisted. ==Second term as president== {{Main article|Second Presidency of Rómulo Betancourt}} [[File:Alliance for Progress in Venezuela 1961.jpg|right|thumb|U.S. President [[John F. Kennedy]] in December 1961 promoting the Alliance for Progress with Venezuelan President Rómulo Betancourt, who had invited Kennedy to this land redistribution ceremony in a Venezuelan village.{{cite book|last1=Rabe|first1=Stephen G.|authorlink=Stephen G. Rabe|title=The Most Dangerous Area in the World: John F. Kennedy Confronts Communist Revolution in Latin America|date=1999|publisher=University of North Carolina press|location=Chapel Hill|isbn=080784764X|page=[https://books.google.no/books?id=hVhuAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA101 101]}} Kennedy's wife, [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jacqueline]], addressed the audience in Spanish. Video of this ceremony [[:File:Kennedy in Latin America 1961 USIS.ogv|can be seen here]].]] A decade later, after Pérez Jiménez was ousted, Betancourt was elected president in the [[Venezuelan general election, 1958|general election of 1958]], becoming the first leader of the [[Punto Fijo Pact]]. Having inherited a well constructed country but with the need to give more education to its people, Betancourt nevertheless managed to return the state to fiscal solvency despite the rock-bottom petroleum prices throughout his presidency. In 1960 two important institutions were created by [[Juan Pablo Pérez Alfonso]], Betancourt's minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons: the Venezuelan Petroleum Corporation (Corporación Venezolana del Petróleo — [[Petróleos de Venezuela S.A.|CVP]]), conceived to oversee the national petroleum industry, and the [[Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries]] ([[OPEC]]), the international oil cartel that Venezuela established in partnership with [[Kuwait]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Iraq]], and [[Iran]]. Considered a radical revolutionary idea at the time by its opponents, but essential to Venezuela's independence and fiscal solvency by a visionary nationalistic Betancourt. At an annual oil convention in Cairo, Venezuela's envoy, fluent in Arabic, convinced oil producing Middle Eastern countries to sign a secret agreement that promoted unity and control of their own national oil resources; under the noses of the British and American corporations that dominated the oil industry globally and had funded the event. Planting the seed for [[OPEC]] that was founded in September 1960 at [[Baghdad]], Iraq. This movement was triggered by a 1960 law instituted by American President [[Dwight Eisenhower]] that forced quotas for Venezuelan oil and favored Canada and Mexico's oil industries. Eisenhower cited national security, land access to energy supplies, at times of war. Betancourt reacted seeking an alliance with oil producing Arab nations as a pre-emptive strategy to protect the continuous autonomy and profitability of Venezuela's oil, establishing a strong link between the South American nation and the Middle East region that survives to this day. ===Agrarian reform=== AD's land reform distributed unproductive private properties and public lands to halt the decline in agricultural production. Landowners who had their properties confiscated received generous compensation. ===FALN guerrilla group=== [[File:Rómulo Betancourt 59.jpg|thumb|Betancourt's inaugural address in 1959]] Betancourt also faced determined opposition from extremists and rebellious army units, yet he continued to push for economic and educational reform. A fraction split from the AD and formed the [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Venezuela)|Revolutionary Left Movement]] (MIR). When leftists were involved in unsuccessful revolts at Barcelona (''[[El Barcelonazo]]'') in 1961 and in navy bases in 1962 (''[[El Carupanazo]]'', [[Carúpano]] and ''[[El Porteñazo]]'', [[Puerto Cabello]]), Betancourt suspended civil liberties. Elements of the left parties then formed the [[Fuerzas Armadas de Liberación Nacional (Venezuela)|Armed Forces for National Liberation]] (FALN), a communist guerrilla army to fight him. This drove the leftists underground, where they engaged in rural and urban guerrilla activities, including sabotaging oil pipelines, bombing a [[Sears Roebuck]] warehouse, [[Alfredo Di Stefano]] kidnapping, and bombing the United States Embassy in Caracas. FALN failed to rally the rural poor and to disrupt the December 1963 elections After numerous attacks, he finally arrested the MIR and [[Communist Party of Venezuela]] (PCV) members of [[National Assembly of Venezuela|Congress]]. It became clear that a leftist [[Fidel Castro]] had been arming the rebels, so Venezuela protested to the [[Organization of American States]] (OAS). ===Assassination attempt=== Betancourt had denounced the dictatorship of [[Dominican Republic]]'s [[Rafael Leonidas Trujillo]] supported by the United States government. In turn, Trujillo had developed an obsessive personal hatred of Betancourt and supported many plots by Venezuelan exiles to overthrow him. This led the Venezuelan government to take its case against Trujillo to the [[Organization of American States|OAS]], turning to diplomacy first over armed response to resolve the political conflict. That in turn infuriated Trujillo, who ordered his foreign agents to assassinate Betancourt in Caracas. The 24 June 1960 attempt, in which the Venezuelan president was badly burned, inflamed world public opinion against Trujillo, who was in turn assassinated by his own people in the Dominican Republic only a year later, May 30, 1961. Photos of a wounded but still living Betancourt were distributed around the world as proof he survived the assassination attempt that killed his head of security, and severely injured the driver who later died. An incendiary [[car bomb]] that was in a parked vehicle was detonated as his presidential car drove by one of [[Caracas]]' main avenues, shocking the nation. With both burned hands wrapped in bandages, Rómulo Betancourt walked out of the hospital in front of photographers. This incident elevated him in the eyes of the public opinion, and helped to destroy one of his most ferocious Caribbean enemies at the same time. === Constitutional government cabinet (1959–1964) === {{Col-begin}} {{Col-1-of-2}} {| cellpadding="1" cellspacing="4" style="margin:1px; border:1px solid Black; float:left" |- !bgcolor="#dcdcdc" colspan=3|MinistriesRómulo Betancourt Foundation (2007). "Political Anthology of Rómulo Betancourt, Seventh Volume 1958–1964." |- |align="left"|'''OFFICE'''||align="left"|'''NAME'''||align="left"|'''TERM''' |- !bgcolor="black" colspan=3| |- |align="left"|[[President of Venezuela|President]]||align="left"|'''Rómulo Betancourt'''||align="left"|1959–1964 |- |align="left"|Home Affairs||align="left"|'''Luis Augusto Dubuc'''||align="left"|1959–1962 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''[[Carlos Andrés Pérez]]'''||align="left"|1962–1963 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Manuel Mantilla'''||align="left"|1963–1964 Briceño'''||align="left"|1960–1964 |- |align="left"|Finance||align="left"|'''José Antonio Mayobre'''||align="left"|1959–1960 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Tomás Enrique Carrillo Batalla'''||align="left"|1960–1961 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Andrés Germán Otero'''||align="left"|1961–1964 |- |align="left"|Defense||align="left"|'''Josué López Pizani'''||align="left"|1959–1960 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Martín Pérez Guevara'''||align="left"|1960–1961 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|''' [[Reinaldo Leandro Mora]] '''||align="left"|1961–1964 |- |align="left"|Justice ||align="left"|'''Andrés Aguilar'''||align="left"|1959–1962 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Miguel Ángel Landáez'''||align="left"|1962–1963 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Ezequiel Monsalve'''||align="left"|1963–1964 |- |align="left"|Mines and Hydrocarbons||align="left"|'''[[Juan Pablo Pérez Alfonso]]'''||align="left"|1959–1963 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Arturo Hernández Grisanti'''||align="left"|1963–1964 |- |align="left"|Labor||align="left"|'''Luis Hernández Solís'''||align="left"|1959–1960 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Raúl Valera'''||align="left"|1960–1963 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Alberto Aranguren Zamora'''||align="left"|1963–1964 |- |align="left"|Communications||align="left"|'''Manuel López Rivas'''||align="left"|1959–1960 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Juan Manuel Domínguez Chacín'''||align="left"|1960 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Pablo Miliani'''||align="left"|1960–1964 |- |align="left"|Agriculture||align="left"|'''Victor Manuel Giménez Landínez'''||align="left"|1959–1963 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Miguel Rodríguez Viso'''||align="left"|1963–1964 |- |align="left"|Health and Social Assistance||align="left"|'''[[Arnoldo Gabaldón]]'''||align="left"|1959–1964 |- |align="left"|Secretary of Presidency||align="left"|'''[[Ramón José Velásquez]]'''||align="left"|1959–1963 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''[[Mariano Picón Salas]]'''||align="left"|1963–1964 |- |align="left"|Office of Coordination and Planification||align="left"|'''Manuel Pérez Guerrero'''||align="left"|1959–1962 |- |align="left"| ||align="left"|'''Héctor Hurtado'''||align="left"|1962–1964 |- |align="left"|[[Corporación Venezolana de Guayana|CVG]]||align="left"|'''[[Rafael Alfonzo Ravard]]'''||align="left"|1960–1964 |} {{Clear}} {{Col-2-of-2}} {{Col-end}} ===1963 elections=== Perhaps one of the greatest of Betancourt's accomplishments, however, was the successful 1963 elections. Despite threats to disrupt the process, nearly 90 percent of the electorate participated on 1 December in what was the most honest election in Venezuela to that date. 11 March 1964 was a day of pride for the people of Venezuela as for the first time the presidential sash passed from one democratically elected chief executive to another. It should be noted prior to Betancourt changing the law, all presidents in Venezuela were elected by Congress – in typical republic model. He was Venezuela's first democratically-elected president to serve his full term, and was succeeded by [[Raúl Leoni]]. It was Romulo Betancourt who established a democratic precedent for the nation that had been ruled by dictatorships for most of its history. It was 'revolution' by popular vote, without historical reference until then; Betancourt created the political model that had survived in Venezuela for many years afterward. ===Betancourt Doctrine=== {{Social democracy sidebar|}} [[File:Rómulo y Militares.jpg|left|thumb|200px|Rómulo Betancourt during a speech to a group of officers]] The Venezuelan president's antipathy for nondemocratic rule was reflected in the so-called Betancourt Doctrine, which denied Venezuelan diplomatic recognition to any regime, right or left, that came to power by military force. Betancourt always defended, and represented, democratic values and principles in Latin America. This put him at odds with the military strongmen who came to dominate and define political perception of the region. During his first message to Congress as President of Venezuela, on 12 February 1959, Betancourt said:
"...Regimes disrespectful of human rights, violating their citizens´ freedom, tyrannizing them with the backing of totalitarian political police, should be submitted to a rigorous sanitary cordon and eradicated, through collective pacification, from the Inter-American juridical community"The Daily Journal, 16 May 1977. (Rómulo Betancourt, The) "Return of the Warrior"
It was during the tense [[Cuban Missile Crisis]], between the United States and Cuba, the relationship between President Kennedy and President Betancourt became closer than ever. Establishing a direct phone link between the White House and Miraflores (Presidential Palace) since the Venezuelan president had ample experience on dealing, defeating and surviving, actions of Caribbean-based pro-soviet regimes against pro-US regimes. These conversations between both presidents were translated by Betancourt's only child, [[Virginia Betancourt|Virginia Betancourt Valverde]], who served as interpreter and confidant to her father. Later president [[Rafael Caldera]] rejected the doctrine, which he thought had served to isolate Venezuela in the world. A thesis that continues to be debated among academics and intellectuals who see in Betancourt not an isolationist but a courageous defender of democratic principles in the midst of adversity and ferreous enemies. ==Later life== [[File:Betancourt playing soccer.JPG|right|thumb|200px|Betancourt playing soccer, c. 1960s]] In 1964, Betancourt was awarded a [[Senator for life|lifetime seat]] in Venezuela's [[National Assembly of Venezuela|senate]], due to status as a former president. His last days were dedicated to writing and to his wife Dr. Renee Hartmann. He died on 28 September 1981 in Doctors Hospital in [[New York City]]. On his death US President [[Ronald Reagan]] made the following statement: :{{cquote|I speak for all Americans in expressing our heartfelt sadness at the death of Romulo Betancourt. While he was first and foremost a Venezuelan patriot, Romulo Betancourt was an especially close friend of the United States. During the 1950s he considered the United States a refuge while he was in exile, and we were proud to receive him. We are honored that this courageous man whose life was dedicated to the principles of liberty and justice – a man who fought dictatorships of the right and the left – spent his final days on our shores. We join the Venezuelan people and those who love freedom around the world in mourning his death.{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=44313|title=Ronald Reagan: Statement on the Death of Former President Romulo Betancourt of Venezuela|publisher=}}}} ==Personal life== Betancourt was married to [[Carmen Valverde]],{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} who served as [[List of First Ladies of Venezuela|First Lady of Venezuela]] from 1945–1948,{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}, and 1959–1964. Virginia Betancourt Valverde was the Betancourt's only child. Divorced he married Dr. Renee Hartmann.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Rómulo Betancourt was a very close friend of the [[Governor of Puerto Rico]], [[Luis Muñoz Marín]], visiting the island often and frequently exchanging political views with him, viewing him as a political advisor on democracy. Although they disagreed on certain issues they remained faithful friends. On one occasion in 1963, he refused to attend the inauguration of [[Juan Bosch (politician)|Juan Bosch]] as president of the Dominican Republic if Bosch did not extend an invitation to Muñoz Marín, who had provided a safe haven for Bosch and various members of his political party in Puerto Rico. Betancourt attended the funeral of his friend in 1980.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} File:Carmen Valverde...jpg|Carmen Valverde File:RomuloyRenee.jpg|Betancourt and Renee Hartmann == Bibliography == [[File:Advertising allusive to Rómulo Betancourt, 1981.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Rómulo... "great spirits do not die". Advertising published after the death of Betancourt in 1981]] *Cecilio Acosta (1928) *Dos meses en las cárceles de Gómez (1928) *En las huellas de la pezuña (1929) *Con quién estamos y contra quién estamos (1932) *Una República en venta (1932) *Problemas venezolanos (1940) *Un reportaje y una conferencia (1941) *El caso de Venezuela y el destino de la democracia en América (1949) *Escuelas y despensa, los dos pivotes de la reforma educacional (1951) *Campos de concentración para los venezolanos y millones de dólares para las compañias petroleras (1952) *Venezuela, factoría petrolera (1954) *Venezuela: política y petróleo (1956) *Posición y Doctrina (1958) *Venezuela rinde cuentas (1962) *Posibilidades y obstáculos de la Revolución Democrática (1965) *Golpes de estado y gobiernos de fuerza en América Latina; la dramática experiencia dominicana (1966) *Latin America: its problems and possibilities (1966) *Hacia una América Latina democrática e integrada (1967) *Venezuela dueña de su petróleo (1975) *José Alberto Velandia: ejemplo para las nuevas generaciones de Venezuela (1975) *El Petróleo de Venezuela (1976) *Acción Democrática, un partido para hacer historia (1976) *El 18 de octubre de 1945. Génesis y realizaciones de una revolución democrática (1979) ==Books== [[File:Rómulo Betancourt´s Personal Library - Pacairigua, Caracas.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Betancourt´s Personal Library - Rómulo Betancourt Foundation, Caracas]] *''Venezuela: Oil & Politics''; 1978; by Rómulo Betancourt; {{ISBN|0-395-27945-3}} *''Rómulo Betancourt''; 1977; by Manuel Caballero *''Rómulo en Berna''; 1978; by Luis González Herrera *''Rómulo Betancourt en la historia de Venezuela del siglo XX''; 1980; by [[Ramón J. Velásquez]], J.F. Sucre Figarella, Blas Bruni Celli *''Rómulo Betancourt and the Transformation of Venezuela''; 1981; by [[Robert J. Alexander]]; {{ISBN|0-87855-450-5}} *''Rómulo y Yo''; 1984; by Renée Hartmann; {{ISBN|84-253-1625-1}} *''Rómulo''; 1984; by Sanin *''Rómulo Betancourt, Político sin ocaso''; 1988; compilation book *''Rómulo Betancourt, Político de Nación''; 2004; by [[Manuel Caballero]]; {{ISBN|980-354-154-4}} *''Rómulo Betancourt''; 2005; by María Teresa Romero; {{ISBN|980-6915-07-0}} *''Mi Abuelo Rómulo''; 2013; by Alvaro Pérez Betancourt and Claudia González Gamboa; {{ISBN|978-980408-022-7}} == See also == {{Portal|Venezuela|Socialism}} *[[Presidents of Venezuela]] *[[List of Venezuelans]] ==References== *[http://www.efemeridesvenezolanas.com/html/romulo.htm Biography at Efemeridesvenezolanas.com] ==External links== {{Commons category|Rómulo Betancourt}} * [http://www.fundaromulobetancourt.org Betancourt Foundation – Official Page] * [http://www.1upinfo.com/country-guide-study/venezuela/venezuela17.html 1Up Info about the Triumph of Democracy] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060323215203/http://www.jfklink.com/speeches/jfk/publicpapers/1961/jfk509_61.html President Kennedy's speech at la Morita] {{S-start}} {{s-off}} {{Succession box| before = [[Isaías Medina Angarita|Isaías Medina]] | title = [[List of Presidents of Venezuela|President of Venezuela]] | years = 1945–1948 | after = [[Rómulo Gallegos]]}} {{Succession box| before = [[Edgar Sanabria]]

[[File:Marchioness of Dalhousie.jpg|thumb|200px|Susan, Marchioness of Dalhousie]] '''Susan Broun-Ramsay, Marchioness of Dalhousie''' (13 March 1817 – 6 May 1853), formerly Lady Susan Georgiana Hay, was the wife of [[James Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie]].
She was the daughter of [[George Hay, 8th Marquess of Tweeddale]], and his wife, the former Lady Susan Montagu.
On 21 January 1836 she married James Broun-Ramsay, who became Earl of Dalhousie in 1838, making her a countess. They had two children: *Lady Susan Georgiana Ramsay (died 1898), who was married twice: first, to [[Robert Bourke, 1st Baron Connemara]], from whom she was divorced in 1890,<ref> L. G. Pine, The New Extinct Peerage 1884-1971: Containing Extinct, Abeyant, Dormant and Suspended Peerages With Genealogies and Arms (London, U.K.: Heraldry Today, 1972), page 82. </ref> and second, to Surgn.-Lt.-Col. William Hamilton Briggs, who took the surname Broun. There were no children from either marriage. *Lady Edith Christian Ramsay (died 1871), who married Rt. Hon. [[Sir James Fergusson, 6th Baronet]], and had children
For a period in 1842, the then countess was a [[Lady of the Bedchamber]] to Queen Victoria, a position also held by her sister [[Elizabeth Wellesley, Duchess of Wellington|Elizabeth]], whose husband was the heir to [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|the Duke of Wellington]]. However, Susan was obliged to resign because of health problems.<ref name="Reynolds1998">{{cite book|author=K. D. Reynolds|title=Aristocratic Women and Political Society in Victorian Britain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fCWQq7VTGZ0C&pg=PA224|year=1998|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-820727-6|pages=224–}}</ref>
In 1848 the earl was made Governor-General of India and Governor of Bengal, and in the following year he was elevated to the rank of marquess. He was accompanied by his wife, but her health deteriorated and in 1852 she moved to [[Ceylon]] in the hope that the climate would help. In 1853 she began the sea journey back to Britain but was taken ill and died before reaching home.<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Ramsay, James Andrew Broun|author=Alexander John Arbuthnot|volume=47}}</ref>
In the absence of a male heir, the marquessate lapsed after the death of James Broun-Ramsay in 1860 and the earldom passed to a nephew.<ref>Mosley, Charles, editor. Burke's Peerage, Baronetage & Knightage, 107th edition, 3 volumes. Wilmington, Delaware, U.S.A.: Burke's Peerage (Genealogical Books) Ltd, 2003. Page 1019.</ref>

{{More footnotes|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox person | name = Truman Bethurum | image = Bethurum.jpg | caption = Truman Bethurum in about 1955 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1898|8|21|mf=y}} | birth_place= | death_date = {{death date and age|1969|5|21|1898|8|21|mf=y}} | death_place= | known_for = Alleged contact with extraterrestrials }} {| class="infobox" style="width:22em" ! colspan=2 class="navbox-abovebelow" | Alleged abduction of Truman Bethurum |- ! Status | Multiple Contactee |- ! Abductor | [[Nordic aliens|Space Brothers]] |- ! colspan=2 class="navbox-abovebelow" | Media |- ! Book | The Voice of the Planet Clarion |} '''Truman Bethurum''' (August 21, 1898 – May 21, 1969) was the second of the well known 1950s ''[[contactees]]'', individuals who claimed to have spoken with people from other inhabited planets and entered or ridden in their spacecraft. His experiences led him to visit and discuss the issue with earlier contactee [[George Adamski]].
Bethurum was born in Gavalin, California, and in the early 1950s worked as a mechanic on a road-building crew and as a [[spirituality|spiritual]] advisor. In 1953 Bethurum first published magazine and newspaper (Redondo Beach ''Daily Breeze'', September 25, 1953) accounts of being contacted on eleven separate occasions by the human crew of a landed space ship, and repeatedly conversing with its voluptuous female captain, Aura Rhanes.<ref>http://www.theironskeptic.com/articles/clarion/clarion.htm A sketch of Aura Rhanes is included</ref> Saucer and crew, who spoke colloquial English, came from the unknown [[planet]] Clarion (allegedly on the other side of our [[moon]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=lteid47_0-kC&pg=PA27&dq=clarion+planet+%22other+side+of+the+moon%22++Bethurum&hl=en&sa=X&ei=v_i5Ub-xI9Dh4APcp4GQCw&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=clarion%20planet%20%22other%20side%20of%20the%20moon%22%20%20Bethurum&f=false Alien Worlds: Social and Religious Dimensions of Extraterrestrial Contact] edited by Diana G. Tumminia, p.27</ref>), which, from the [[earth]], always remains out of sight. A 1954 book, ''Aboard a Flying Saucer'', gave many details of Bethurum's suffering at the hands of skeptics and a great deal of information about Clarion and its people.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=BRHoKVTawnMC&pg=PA20&dq=ufos+from+another+planet+behind+the+sun&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1c6vUKOkBuSqyAHBv4GABg&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=ufos%20from%20another%20planet%20behind%20the%20sun&f=false The Ufo Book of Lists]| By STEPHEN J SPIGNESI, Stephen J. Spignesi|</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=pyv7UIBojboC&pg=PA115&dq=Aboard+a+Flying+Saucer%27%27+by+Truman+Bethurum&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UdCvUK-5GaSuyQHV_IHYCA&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Aboard%20a%20Flying%20Saucer%27%27%20by%20Truman%20Bethurum&f=false Strange Secrets: Real Government Files on the Unknown] By Nick Redfern, Andy Roberts]</ref>
Most contactees of this period became (or already were) leaders in new paradigm movements to inform people of extraterrestrial intelligent life, including [[George Adamski]], [[George Van Tassel]], [[Daniel Fry]], [[Aetherius Society|George King]] and many others. Mr Bethurum made it known that the space people had asked him to consider creating a place of learning for those who were interested in considering the possibility of extraterrestrial intelligent life, with Mr Bethurum as facilitator. The ''Sanctuary of Thought'', a philosophical group, was subsequently created near Prescott, Arizona. Mr Bethurum claimed to possess physical evidence such as unique items given to him by Captain Aura Rhanes.
Some of Bethurum's later books include ''The Voice of the Planet Clarion'' (1957), ''Facing Reality'' (1958), and ''The People of the Planet Clarion'' (1970), published after his death in [[Landers, California]] in 1969. The first 44 pages of the final book are an autobiography of Bethurum covering his life up to 1953. [[Columba Krebs]] wrote the afterword.
Mr Bethurum himself jokingly remarked in his many public lectures that his second wife had divorced him in 1955 mainly due to jealousy of Captain Rhanes. He later married a third time, with the wedding taking place at one of Mr George Van Tassel's popular yearly ''Giant Rock Spacecraft Conventions''.
==See also== * ''[[When Prophecy Fails]]'' (a book about Dorothy Martin who claimed to have received prophetic messages from the planet Clarion)

A currently available reprint of Bethurum's last book.

revision.comment: Undid revision 857511660 by [[Special:Contributions/2402:3A80:98F:E73E:9733:E054:978E:EEE7|2402:3A80:98F:E73E:9733:E054:978E:EEE7]] ([[User talk:2402:3A80:98F:E73E:9733:E054:978E:EEE7|talk]]) contradicted by all four of the sources cited in the section
revision.text:
{{Coord|40.757682|-73.98571|region:US_type:landmark|display=title}} {{italic title}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} [[File:Legendary kiss V–J day in Times Square Alfred Eisenstaedt.jpg|thumb|right|''V-J Day in Times Square'', a photograph by Alfred Eisenstaedt, was published in ''Life'' in 1945 with the caption, "In New York's Times Square a white-clad girl clutches her purse and skirt as an uninhibited sailor plants his lips squarely on hers"]] [[File:Eisenstaedt signing "VJ day" print on August 23, 1995 at his Menemsha cabin on Martha's Vineyard.jpg|thumb|right|Alfred Eisenstaedt signing his famous ''V-J Day'' photograph on the afternoon of August 23, 1995, while sitting in his Menemsha Inn cabin located on Martha's Vineyard. He died about eight hours later.]]
'''''V-J Day in Times Square''''' (also '''''V-Day''''' and '''''The Kiss''''')<ref>{{cite book |chapter = ''V-J Day in Times Square'' |title = The Photo Book |location = London |publisher = Phaeton |year = 2000 |isbn = 0-7148-3937-X |page = 134}} {{cite book |chapter = ''V-Day'' |title = Twentieth Century Photography: Museum Ludwig Cologne |location = Cologne |publisher = Taschen |year = 2005 |isbn = 3-8228-4083-1 |pages = 148–149 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/thedailymirror/2010/06/voices-edith-shain-and-the-kiss.html |title = The Daily Mirror: Voices -- Edith Shain and 'The Kiss' |author = Harnisch, Larry |date = August 14, 2005 |work = Los Angeles Times |publisher = Tribune Company |accessdate = June 3, 2011 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6Fl7VrZl1?url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/thedailymirror/2010/06/voices-edith-shain-and-the-kiss.html |archivedate = April 9, 2013 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> is a photograph by [[Alfred Eisenstaedt]] that portrays a [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] [[sailor]] grabbing and kissing a stranger—a woman in a white dress—on [[Victory over Japan Day]] ("V-J Day") in [[New York City]]'s [[Times Square]] on August 14, 1945.<ref name=consent/> The photograph was published a week later in ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine, among many photographs of celebrations around the United States that were presented in a twelve-page section titled "Victory Celebrations".<ref>{{cite news |title = V-J Day, 1945: A Nation Lets Loose |work = [[Life (magazine)|Life]] |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=e0gEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q&f=false |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180314173507/https://books.google.com/books?id=e0gEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q&f=false |archivedate = March 14, 2018 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> A two-page spread faces three other kissing poses among celebrators in [[Washington, D.C.]]; [[Kansas City]]; and [[Miami]] opposite Eisenstaedt's, which was given a full-page display. Kissing was a favorite pose encouraged by media photographers of service personnel during [[World War II|the war]],{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} but Eisenstaedt was photographing a spontaneous event that occurred in Times Square soon before the announcement of the end of the [[Pacific War|war with Japan]] was made by U.S. President [[Harry S. Truman]] at seven o'clock.
Because he was photographing rapidly changing events during the celebrations, Eisenstaedt did not have an opportunity to get the names and details.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} The photograph does not clearly show the face of either person involved, and numerous people have claimed to be the subjects. The photograph was shot just south of 45th Street looking north from a location where [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] and [[Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)|Seventh Avenue]] converge.
The photograph was taken at 5:51 p.m. ET, according to Donald W. Olson and his team.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2015/08/14/story-behind--kiss-vj-day/31676791/ |title = Mystery Clouds Times Square kiss for 70 years |work = [[USA Today]] |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160911134216/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2015/08/14/story-behind--kiss-vj-day/31676791/ |archivedate = September 11, 2016 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> It was taken with a [[Leica III]]a.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://life.time.com/history/v-j-day-kiss-in-times-square-and-other-celebrations-august-14-1945/#1 |title = V-J Day, 1945: A Nation Lets Loose |work = Life |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130901154612/http://life.time.com/history/v-j-day-kiss-in-times-square-and-other-celebrations-august-14-1945/#1 |archivedate = September 1, 2013 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
==Accounts by Alfred Eisenstaedt== In two different books he wrote, Alfred Eisenstaedt gave two slightly different accounts of taking the photograph and of its nature.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
From ''Eisenstaedt on Eisenstaedt'':
{{Quote|1=In Times Square on V.J. Day I saw a sailor running along the street grabbing any and every girl in sight. Whether she was a grandmother, stout, thin, old, didn't make a difference. I was running ahead of him with my [[Leica Camera|Leica]] looking back over my shoulder but none of the pictures that were possible pleased me. Then suddenly, in a flash, I saw something white being grabbed. I turned around and clicked the moment the sailor kissed the nurse. If she had been dressed in a dark dress I would never have taken the picture. If the sailor had worn a white uniform, the same. I took exactly four pictures. It was done within a few seconds.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
Only one is right, on account of the balance. In the others the emphasis is wrong — the sailor on the left side is either too small or too tall. People tell me that when I am in heaven they will remember this picture.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}}}
From ''The Eye of Eisenstaedt'':
{{quote|1=I was walking through the crowds on V-J Day, looking for pictures. I noticed a sailor coming my way. He was grabbing every female he could find and kissing them all — young girls and old ladies alike. Then I noticed the nurse, standing in that enormous crowd. I focused on her, and just as I'd hoped, the sailor came along, grabbed the nurse, and bent down to kiss her. Now if this girl hadn't been a nurse, if she'd been dressed dark clothes, I wouldn't have had a picture. The contrast between her white dress and the sailor's dark uniform gives the photograph its extra impact.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}}}
It became a [[cultural icon]] overnight and by establishing his copyright, Eisenstaedt carefully controlled the rights to it, only allowing a limited number of reproductions which determined how it could be used.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
==Another photograph of the same scene== [[File:Kissing the War Goodbye.jpg|thumb|right|Jorgensen's similar photograph]] U.S. Navy [[Photojournalism|photo journalist]] [[Victor Jorgensen]] captured another view of the same scene, which was published in ''[[The New York Times]]'' the following day.<ref name="COLUMBIA-FORUM">{{cite web |date = March–April 2007 |url = http://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/mar_apr07/forum.php |title = Everyman in Times Square |publisher = Columbia Forum |access-date = September 24, 2007 |first = Marshall |last = Berman |quote = They were also photographed at just about the same moment, from a slightly different (and less exciting) angle, by U.S. Navy photographer Victor Jorgensen; Jorgensen's photo was printed in the next day's ''New York Times''. |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070829024522/http://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/mar_apr07/forum.php |archivedate = August 29, 2007 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> Jorgensen titled his photograph ''Kissing the War Goodbye''. It shows less of Times Square in the background, lacking the characteristic view of the complex intersection so that the location needs to be identified, it is dark and shows few details of the main subjects, and it does not show the lower legs and feet of the subjects.
Unlike the Eisenstaedt photograph, which is protected by [[copyright]], this Navy photograph is in the [[public domain]] as it was produced by a federal government employee on official duty. While the angle of the photograph may be less interesting than that of Eisenstaedt's photo, it clearly shows the actual location of the iconic kiss occurring in the front of the [[Chemical Bank|Chemical Bank and Trust]] building, with the [[Walgreens]] pharmacy signage on the building façade visible in the background.
The surprised woman on the left in Jorgensen's photograph has been positively identified as Kay Hughes Dorius of Utah.<ref>{{cite news |first = Natalie |last = Andrews |date = November 10, 2006 |url = http://www.heraldextra.com/news/the-other-woman-in-the-wwii-kiss-photo/article_5e1391d9-d15f-5039-aee5-174068647290.html |title = The other woman in the WWII 'kiss" photo |work = Daily Herald |access-date = September 14, 2015 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150916092517/http://www.heraldextra.com/news/the-other-woman-in-the-wwii-kiss-photo/article_5e1391d9-d15f-5039-aee5-174068647290.html |archivedate = September 16, 2015 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
==Identity of the kissers==
===Greta Zimmer Friedman===
Lawrence Verria and George Galdorisi, authors of ''The Kissing Sailor'', a 2012 book about the identity of the couple, used interviews of claimants, expert photo analysis, identifying people in the background and consultations with forensic anthropologists and facial recognition specialists. They concluded that the woman was [[Greta Zimmer Friedman]] and that she was wearing her dental hygienist uniform in the photograph.<ref name=bell/>
"It wasn't my choice to be kissed," Friedman stated in a 2005 interview with the [[Library of Congress]].<ref name=consent>{{cite web |url = http://memory.loc.gov/diglib/vhp/story/loc.natlib.afc2001001.42863/transcript?ID=sr0001 |title = Interview Transcript: Greta Zimmer Friedman: Veterans History Project (Library of Congress) |website = American Memory |first = Patricia |last = Redmond |date = August 23, 2005 |accessdate = September 12, 2016 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160916153530/http://memory.loc.gov/diglib/vhp/story/loc.natlib.afc2001001.42863/transcript?ID=sr0001 |archivedate = September 16, 2016 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> "The guy just came over and grabbed!" she said, adding, "That man was very strong. I wasn't kissing him. He was kissing me."<ref name=consent/><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/famed-image-marking-v-j-day-sinister-shade-article-1.2774540 |title = How a celebrated image marking V-J Day in Times Square has taken on a sinister shade |work = [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |location = New York |first = Andy |last = Martino |date = September 2, 2016 |accessdate = September 12, 2016 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160916153531/http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/famed-image-marking-v-j-day-sinister-shade-article-1.2774540 |archivedate = September 16, 2016 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> "I did not see him approaching, and before I know it I was in this tight grip," Friedman told CBS News in 2012.<ref name=cbs>{{cite news |url = http://www.cbsnews.com/news/greta-friedman-woman-kissed-in-iconic-v-j-day-photo-dead-at-92/ |title = Woman in V-J Day photo dead at 92 |last = |first = |date = September 10, 2016 |publisher = CBS News |access-date = September 10, 2016 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160911013846/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/greta-friedman-woman-kissed-in-iconic-v-j-day-photo-dead-at-92/ |archivedate = September 11, 2016 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> Friedman died at age 92 on September 8, 2016, in Richmond, Virginia, due to age related health complications.<ref name=latimes>{{cite news |url = http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-greta-friedman-20160910-snap-story.html |title = Greta Friedman, woman in iconic WWII Times Square kiss photograph, dies at 92 |last = |first = |date = September 10, 2016 |work = [[Los Angeles Times]] |access-date = September 11, 2016 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160911045333/http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-greta-friedman-20160910-snap-story.html |archivedate = September 11, 2016 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
===Edith Shain=== [[File:Edith Shain.jpg|thumb|Edith Shain at the 2008 Memorial Day parade in [[Washington, D.C.]]]]
Edith Shain wrote to Eisenstaedt in 1980 claiming to be the woman in the picture.<ref name=posed>{{cite web |last1 = Lucas |first1 = Dean |work = Famous Pictures Magazine |title = VJday Times Square Kiss |date = April 17, 2007 |url = http://www.famouspictures.org/vjday-times-square-kiss/ |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130718145945/http://www.famouspictures.org/vjday-times-square-kiss/ |archivedate = July 18, 2013 |df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1 = Wadler |first1 = Joyce |title = The Shot Seen Round the World |work = The Washington Post |date = August 16, 1980 |page = D1 |quote=Then, 35 years later, the nurse, a Mrs. Edith Shain, 62, from Beverly Hills, broke the silence. Contacted the photographer, Alfred Eisenstaedt, identified herself, and asked for a print. At Life, where the publisher keeps the picture on his wall, there was great jubilation.}}</ref> In August 1945, Shain was working at [[Doctors Hospital (Manhattan)|Doctor's Hospital]] in [[Manhattan, New York City]] as a nurse when she and a friend heard on the radio that [[World War II]] had ended. They went to Times Square where all the celebrating was and as soon as she arrived on the street from the subway, the sailor grabbed her in an embrace and kissed her. She related that at the time she thought she might as well let him kiss her since he fought for her in the war.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Shain did not claim that she was the woman in the white dress until many years later when she wrote to Eisenstaedt. He notified the magazine that he had received her letter claiming to be the subject.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
On June 20, 2010, Shain died at age 91 of [[liver cancer]].<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/24/nyregion/24shain.html?ref=obituaries |title = Edith Shain, Who Said Famous Kiss Came Her Way, Dies at 91 |date = June 22, 2010 |accessdate = June 22, 2010 |work = The New York Times |first = Richard |last = Goldstein |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140325060033/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/24/nyregion/24shain.html?ref=obituaries |archivedate = March 25, 2014 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> Verria and Galdorisi's 2012 book stated that Shain could not have been the woman because her height of just {{convert|4|ft|10|in|abbr=on}} was insufficient in comparison with the height of any of the men claiming to be the sailor.<ref name=bell>{{cite news |first = Diane |last = Bell |url = http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2012/apr/20/famous-kissing-sailor-photo-sparks-true-detective/?page=1#article |title = Famous 'kissing sailor' photo sparks true detective tale |work = U-T San Diego |date = April 20, 2012 }}</ref>
===Claiming to be the U.S. Navy sailor=== Numerous men have claimed to be the sailor, including Donald Bonsack, John Edmonson, Wallace C. Fowler, Clarence "Bud" Harding, Walker Irving, James Kearney, Marvin Kingsburg, Arthur Leask, George Mendonça, Jack Russell, and Bill Swicegood.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.life.com/Life/special/kiss03.html/ |title = Who is the Kissing Sailor? |work = Life |date = October 1980 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071019055308/http://www.life.com/Life/special/kiss03.html |archivedate = October 19, 2007 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
====George Mendonsa==== [[File:George Mendonca and Greta Friedman.jpg|thumb|George Mendonsa and Greta Friedman, guests of honor at the Bristol, Rhode Island, July 4 parade in 2009]] George Mendonsa of [[Newport, Rhode Island]], on leave from the {{USS|The Sullivans|DD-537}}, was watching a movie with his future wife, Rita,<ref name="posed"/> at [[Radio City Music Hall]] when the doors opened and people started screaming the war was over.<ref name=whdh20130825/> George and Rita joined the partying on the street, but when they could not get into the packed bars decided to walk down the street. It was then that George saw a woman in a white dress walk by and took her into his arms and kissed her, "I had quite a few drinks that day and I considered her one of the troops—she was a nurse."<ref name="posed"/> In one of the four pictures that Eisenstaedt took, Mendonsa claims that Rita is visible in the background behind the kissing couple.<ref name="posed"/>
In 1987, George Mendonsa filed a lawsuit against Time Inc. in Rhode Island state court, alleging that he was the sailor in the photograph and that both ''Time'' and ''Life'' had violated his right of publicity by using the photograph without his permission.<ref>{{cite court |url = http://www.leagle.com/decision/19881645678FSupp967_11471 |litigants = Mendonsa v. Time Inc. |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141123024610/http://www.leagle.com/decision/19881645678FSupp967_11471 |archive-date=November 23, 2014 |vol = 678 |reporter= F.Supp |opinion = 967 |court = D. R.I. |year = 1988 }}</ref> Unable to match Time Inc.'s deep pockets, Mendonsa dropped his lawsuit in 1988.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Verria |first1=Lawrence |last2=Galdorisi |first2=George |year=2012 |title=The Kissing Sailor: The Mystery Behind the Photo That Ended World War II |location=Annapolis, MD |publisher=Naval Institute Press |page=118 |isbn=9-781612-510781}}</ref>
Mendonsa was identified by a team of volunteers from the [[Naval War College]] in August 2005 as "the kisser". His claim was based on matching his scars and tattoos to scars and tattoos in the photograph.<ref name="posed"/> They made their determination after much study including photographic analysis by the [[Mitsubishi Electric Research Laboratories]] (MERL) in Cambridge, Massachusetts, who were able to match scars and tattoo spotted by photograph experts, and the testimony of Richard M. Benson, a photograph analysis expert, professor of photographic studies, plus the former Dean of the [[School of Arts at Yale University]]. Benson stated that "it is therefore my opinion, based upon a reasonable degree of certainty, that George Mendonsa is the sailor in Mr. Eisenstaedt's famous photograph."<ref name="posed"/>
The identity of the sailor as George Mendonsa has been challenged by physicists Donald W. Olson and Russell Doescher of Texas State University and Steve Kawaler of Iowa State University based on astronomical conditions recorded by the photographs of the incident. According to Mendonsa's account of the events of the day, the kiss would have occurred at approximately 2 p.m. However, Olson and Doescher argue that the positions of shadows in the photographs suggest that it was taken after 5 p.m. They further point to a clock seen in the picture, its minute hand near the 10 and its hour hand pointing virtually vertically downward, indicating a time of approximately 5:50, and to Victor Jorgensen's account of the circumstances of his own picture. They concluded that Mendonsa's version of events is untenable.<ref name=skytelescope>{{cite journal |last1 = Olson |first1 = Donald W. |last2 = Doescher |first2 = Russell L. |last3 = Kawaler |first3 = Steven D. |title = Telltale Sun & Shadow: Astronomy & the VJ Day Kiss |journal = Sky and Telescope |date = August 2015 |pages = 30–35 |url = http://www.skyandtelescope.com/wp-content/uploads/VJDay.pdf |accessdate = January 29, 2016 }}</ref>
====Carl Muscarello==== Carl Muscarello is a retired police officer with the [[New York City Police Department]], now living in [[Plantation, Florida]]. In 1995, he claimed to be the kissing sailor. He claimed that he was in Times Square on August 14, 1945, and that he kissed numerous women. A distinctive birthmark on his hand enabled his mother to identify him as the subject. Edith Shain initially said she believed Muscarello's claim to be the sailor and they even dated after their brief reunion. But in 2005, Shain was much less certain, telling the ''New York Times,'' "I can't say he isn't. I just can't say he is. There is no way to tell."<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/15/nyregion/15kiss.html/ |title = V-J Day Is Replayed, but the Lip-Lock's Tamer This Time |work = The New York Times |date = August 15, 2005 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150210223109/http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/15/nyregion/15kiss.html |archivedate = February 10, 2015 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> Muscarello has described his condition on August 14, 1945 as being quite drunk<ref>{{cite news |first = Carli |last = Teproff |url = http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2010-10-14/news/fl-kissing-sailor-20101014_1_kiss-carl-muscarello-submarines |title = WWII 'Kissing Sailor' Carl Muscarello visits Fort Lauderdale school kids |work = Sun-Sentinel |date = October 14, 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150210180358/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2010-10-14/news/fl-kissing-sailor-20101014_1_kiss-carl-muscarello-submarines |archivedate = February 10, 2015 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> and having no clear memory of his actions in the square, stating that his mother claimed he was the man after seeing the photograph and he came to believe it.<ref>{{cite news |first = Sarah |last = Mirza |url = http://www.cbsnews.com/2100-201_162-6612067.html |title = A Smooch For History |publisher = CBS News |date = June 23, 2010 }}</ref>
====Glenn McDuffie==== Glenn McDuffie laid claim in 2007 and was supported by [[Houston Police Department]] forensic artist [[Lois Gibson]].<ref>{{cite news |first = Juan A. |last = Lozano |url = http://www.newsobserver.com/1565/story/659188.html |title = Forensic expert: N.C. native is sailor in famous wartime photo |work = The News and Observer |date = August 3, 2007 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=Imzadi1979 |fix-attempted=yes }} {{cite news |first = Juan A. |last = Lozano |url = https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070803/ap_on_re_us/kissing_sailor_1;_ylt=AtZvuKNpyW0vDj.Ywu_On9dsaMYA |title = Man says he's the sailor in famous photo |agency = Associated Press |date = August 3, 2007 |work = Yahoo! News }}</ref> Gibson's forensic analysis compared the Eisenstaedt photographs with current-day photographs of McDuffie, analyzing key facial features identical on both sets. She measured his ears, facial bones, hairline, wrist, knuckles, and hand, and compared those to enlargements of Eisenstaedt's picture.
{{quote|1=I could tell just in general that yes, it's him. But I wanted to be able to tell other people so I replicated the pose.<ref>{{cite news |first = Juan A. |last = Lozano |url = http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory?id=3445114 |title = Man Says He's the Sailor in Famous Photo |publisher = ABC News |agency = Associated Press |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071115200732/http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory?id=3445114 |archivedate = November 15, 2007 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>}}
In the August 14, 2007, issue of ''[[AM New York]]'' McDuffie said he passed five [[polygraph]] tests confirming his claim to be the man.<ref name=AM>Dispute over famed smooch – AM New York – August 14, 2007{{full citation needed|date = June 2017}}</ref> McDuffie, a native of [[Kannapolis, North Carolina]], who had lied about his age so he could enlist at the age of 15, went on after the war to play semi-pro [[baseball]] and work for the [[United States Postal Service]].<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.independenttribune.com/news/article_8214a1b2-abc5-11e3-9ae0-0017a43b2370.html |title = Kannapolis sailor in iconic WWII photo dies in Houston |work = [[Independent Tribune]] |accessdate = March 15, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.ajc.com/news/news/national/kissing-sailor-famous-wwii-photograph-dies/nfDT3/ |title = 'Kissing sailor' from famous WWII photograph dies |work = [[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |accessdate = March 15, 2014 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140315155838/http://www.ajc.com/news/news/national/kissing-sailor-famous-wwii-photograph-dies/nfDT3/ |archivedate = March 15, 2014 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> He says that on that day he was on the subway to Brooklyn to visit his girlfriend, Ardith Bloomfield.<ref name=AM/> He came out of the subway at Times Square, where people were celebrating in the streets. Excited that his brother, who was being held by the Japanese as a prisoner of war, would be released, McDuffie began hollering and jumping up and down. A nurse saw him, and opened her arms to him. In apparent conflict with Eisenstaedt's recollections of the event, McDuffie said he ran over to her and kissed her for a long time so that Eisenstaedt could take the photograph:
{{quote|1=I went over there and kissed her and saw a man running at us...I thought it was a jealous husband or boyfriend coming to poke me in the eyes. I looked up and saw he was taking the picture and I kissed her as long as took for him to take it.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/OnlyinAmerica/story?id=3422191&page=1/ |title = Man Claims He's the Mystery Sailor in ''The Kiss'' |publisher = ABC News |date = August 7, 2007 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110521201917/http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/OnlyinAmerica/story?id=3422191&page=1%2F |archivedate = May 21, 2011 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>}}
Gibson had also analyzed photographs of other men who have claimed to be the sailor, including Muscarello and Mendonça, reporting that neither man's facial bones or other features match those of the sailor in the photograph. On August 3, 2008, Glenn McDuffie was recognized for his 81st birthday as the "Kissing Sailor" during the [[seventh-inning stretch]] of the [[Houston Astros]] and [[New York Mets]] game at [[Minute Maid Park]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} McDuffie died on March 14, 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/glenn-mcduffie-man-known-as-kissing-sailor-in-wwii-era-photo-dead-at-86-1.2573355 |title = Glenn McDuffie, man known as kissing sailor in WWII-era photo, dead at 86 |publisher = [[CBC News]].com |accessdate = March 15, 2014 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140315034853/http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/glenn-mcduffie-man-known-as-kissing-sailor-in-wwii-era-photo-dead-at-86-1.2573355 |archivedate = March 15, 2014 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
====Other people==== ''Life''{{'}}s October 1980 issue did not include Muscarello or Glenn McDuffie.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/08/06/that-times-square-smooch-right-to-the-kisser/ |title = When a Kiss Isn't Just a Kiss |work = The New York Times |date = August 6, 2007 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070825030813/http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/08/06/that-times-square-smooch-right-to-the-kisser/ |archivedate = August 25, 2007 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> These claims have been made much more recently.
Mendonça and Friedman (both individually and together), as well as Shain, Muscarello, and McDuffie, were widely interviewed in the succeeding years by ''Life'', PBS, NBC, CBS, and others. Mendonça recognizes Friedman, to the exclusion of any other woman, as the "nurse" he kissed in the photographs (or, to be precise, the woman in the white uniform, as Friedman was a dental assistant—a nurse's uniform was customary in a dentist's office to be worn by female assistants and hygienists in that era).<ref>{{cite book |first = Christina |last = Bates |title = A Cultural History of the Nurse's Uniform |publisher = Canadian Museum of Civilization, |year = 2012 |isbn = 978-0660201849 }}</ref> As part of a World War II memorial at [[Battleship Cove]] in [[Fall River, Massachusetts]], a new painting titled ''Victory Kiss'' by Jim Laurier of New Hampshire was first unveiled on August 24, 2013, to honor the event captured in the photo. George Mendonça was in attendance for the unveiling.<ref name=whdh20130825>{{cite web |url = http://www1.whdh.com/news/articles/local/south/10011509847987/iconic-wwii-painting-unveiled-at-battleship-cove/ |title = Iconic WWII painting unveiled at Battleship Cove |author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date = August 25, 2013 |publisher = WHDH-TV |accessdate = August 25, 2013 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130827125339/http://www1.whdh.com/news/articles/local/south/10011509847987/iconic-wwii-painting-unveiled-at-battleship-cove/ |archivedate = August 27, 2013 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
== Alternate interpretations == The original interpretations of the photo centered around the jubilation of the V-J Day celebrations. Art critic Michael Kimmelman summarized the composition in 1997 as reflective of that mood: the sailor representing returning troops, the nurse to represent those who would welcome them home, and Times Square stood for home. Since then, bloggers in the 2010s have called the photo documentation of a type of normalized [[sexual assault]]. The people pictured in the photograph did not previously know one another. Drunk at the time of the photograph, the sailor is shown kissing an unwilling partner. The widely agreed upon identity of the female subject in the photo, dental assistant [[Greta Zimmer Friedman]], had also explicitly expressed that the kiss in question was not a consensual act. Combined with the humorous expressions on the bystanders and the sailor's firm grasp of the nurse, the situation has been described as emblematic of a time when women were "subordinated to men", or of a [[rape culture]].<ref name=popcult>{{Cite book|title=Popular Culture|last=Gronseth|first=Michael|publisher=Cognella|year=2015|isbn=978-1634872881|editor-last=Howell|editor-first=Mark|edition=1st|location=|pages=47–52|chapter=A Kiss Is Just A Kiss... Or Is It?}}</ref>
==In popular culture== [[File:Unconditional Surrender sculpture Aug 13 2015.jpg|thumb|right|The ''[[Unconditional Surrender (sculpture)|Unconditional Surrender]]'' sculpture in [[Times Square]], [[New York City]] ]]
In 2005, [[John Seward Johnson II]] displayed a bronze life-size sculpture, ''[[Unconditional Surrender (sculpture)|Unconditional Surrender]]'', at an August 14, 2005, sixtieth-anniversary reenactment at Times Square of the kiss. His statue was featured in a ceremony that included Carl Muscarello and Edith Shain, holding a copy of the famous photograph, as participants.<ref>{{cite news |work = The Huffington Post |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/08/13/w-hotels-wwii-kiss-reenac_n_679109.html#s125398 |title = W Hotels' WWII Kiss Reenactment Contest (Photos) |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100819123716/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/08/13/w-hotels-wwii-kiss-reenac_n_679109.html#s125398 |archivedate = August 19, 2010 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> Johnson also sculpted a {{convert|25|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} version in plastic and aluminum, which has been displayed in several cities, including San Diego and Sarasota.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/20274 |title = Unconditional Surrender Statue|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514033612/http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/20274 |archive-date=May 14, 2013|work = Roadside America }}</ref><ref name="pincus">{{cite news |first = Robert L. |last = Pincus |url = http://ww.uniontrib.com/uniontrib/20070311/news_lz1a11kitsch.html |title = Port surrenders in the battle against kitsch |work = San Diego Union-Tribune |date = March 11, 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110717163229/http://ww.uniontrib.com/uniontrib/20070311/news_lz1a11kitsch.html |archivedate = July 17, 2011 |df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last = Ogles |first = Jacob |url = http://www.srqmagazine.com/JMailer/showMassMail.cfm?masID=1967 |title = Unconditional Surrender Deal to Be Finalized Today |work = SRQ Daily |date = June 11, 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120304024828/http://www.srqmagazine.com/JMailer/showMassMail.cfm?masID=1967 |archivedate = March 4, 2012 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> The {{convert|25|ft|adj=on}} version was moved to New York City again on August 12, 2015, for a temporary display.<ref name="observer 20150812">{{cite web |url = http://observer.com/2015/08/monumental-and-controversial-kissing-sailor-sculpture-comes-to-times-square/ |title = Monumental—and Controversial—'Kissing Sailor' Sculpture Comes to Times Square |work = The Observer |date = August 12, 2015 |accessdate = August 13, 2015 |first = Alanna |last = Martinez |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150813082823/http://observer.com/2015/08/monumental-and-controversial-kissing-sailor-sculpture-comes-to-times-square/ |archivedate = August 13, 2015 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
In the 2009 film ''[[Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian]]'', two characters jump into a life-size enlargement of the photograph, finding themselves in a monochrome Times Square. One of them cuts in on the sailor for a kiss with the nurse.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
In the 2009 film ''[[Watchmen (film)|Watchmen]]'', during the opening credits, the Times Square V-J celebration is shown with a costumed heroine, ''[[List of Watchmen characters#Minor characters|Silhouette]]'', kissing a female nurse as a photographer captures the moment.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
In the 2010 film ''[[Letters to Juliet]]'', the photograph is featured in a scene where a magazine editor questions a writer about her fact-checking regarding the image.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
In ''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[Bart the General]]", victory celebrations following a "war" between two groups of children include a boy in a sailor outfit kissing Lisa as a photograph is taken. She then slaps the boy, exclaiming, "Knock it off!"{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
In 2012, while performing a show for the Marines during the New York City [[Fleet Week]], singer [[Katy Perry]] kissed a man on stage, replicating the pose.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.usatodayeducate.com/staging/index.php/ccp/katy-perry-kisses-marine-during-nyc-fleet-week |title = Katy Perry kisses Marine during NYC Fleet Week |last = Bidwill |first = Colleen |work = USA Today |date = May 25, 2012 |accessdate = May 29, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120701190335/http://www.usatodayeducate.com/staging/index.php/ccp/katy-perry-kisses-marine-during-nyc-fleet-week|archivedate=July 1, 2012 }}</ref>
In the 2014 video game ''[[Wolfenstein: The New Order]]'', an alternative history version of the V-J Day kiss (V-A Day in the timeline) appears as a Nazi soldier forcing himself on the nurse.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://uproxx.com/gammasquad/2013/06/its-nazis-nazis-everywhere-in-the-latest-wolfenstein-the-new-order-trailer/ |title = It's Nazis, Nazis Everywhere In The Latest 'Wolfenstein: The New Order' Trailer |first = Nathan |last = Birch |date = June 7, 2013 |accessdate = November 14, 2015 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151222231306/http://uproxx.com/gammasquad/2013/06/its-nazis-nazis-everywhere-in-the-latest-wolfenstein-the-new-order-trailer/ |archivedate = December 22, 2015 |df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = Wolfenstein: The New Order Trailer - E3 2013 |url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JA1QB-h1c4I |date = June 10, 2013 |accessdate = November 14, 2015 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150708125719/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JA1QB-h1c4I |archivedate = July 8, 2015 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
